--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@y...> wrote:
> [snip...]
> 
> > >         Again this brings home to me that any evolving 
software technique
> > >really needs functional, automatic modularity before it has any 
hope of
> > >breaking into the BIG problems.  Modularity entails a trade off 
very like
> > >(5) in that the presence of modularity increases the size of 
the overall
> > >search space (adding choices about how to define modules) but 
hugely
> > >decreases the size of the parts that are considered at one time 
(e.g. each
> > >modules fitness landscape is much, much smaller than the 
overall fitness
> > >landscape.).
> > >
> > >
> >In the mean time it's a good idea to investigate the limits of 
direct
> >encoding techniques such as NEAT. With a great many experiments 
and all
> >ideas exhausted research can them move on to modular or indirect
> >approaches, using the best direct encoding technques as a 
benchmark.  I
> >also think that NEAT could form the core of an indirect encoding
> >technique in the future, finding sub-solutions that can then be
> >recombined into larger solutions. I think I just walked into that 
trap
> >of thinking in a 'divide and conquer' / engineering manner 
again :)
> 
> I'm not sure that I agree.
> 
> Hmm, let me rephrase, I agree that NEAT is an exciting technique 
and well 
> worthy of all the exploration we can get.
> 
> But..., I'm not sure that the progression to modular systems is 
necessarily 
> a _consequence_ of sufficient non-modular research.
> 
> Maybe this is the same doubt as you imply in your final sentence?
> 
> I'm also not sure I necessarily equate the "indirect" 
with "modular".  I 
> mean there is some quite solid thought suggesting that indirect 
encoding is 
> a major approach to modularity (e.g. in nature).  Or even, 
reversing the 
> viewpoint, that by the time you've added enough bells-and-whistles 
to 
> support modularity, you will find the representations no longer 
very 
> direct.  But I think it's worth taking care to keep the concepts 
separate 
> for the moment...
> 

I would also point out that NEAT can be used with an indirect 
encoding.  Genes that produce "proteins" that then activate other 
genes etc., can be tracked with historical markings just like any 
other kind of gene, and those markings can be used to speciate the 
population and start minimally.  So it's not necessary to use NEAT 
as a system for evolving modules that are composed by some higher-
level system (as in Joe Reisinger's already-completed work).  
Instead, NEAT can evolve genuine indirectly encoded structures.

ken
